**Revised Abstract (235 words):**
Accurate regional climate projections are essential for informing adaptation strategies, yet individual global climate models (GCMs) often exhibit systematic biases that limit their utility at sub‑continental scales. To address this limitation, we develop a multi‑model ensemble (MME) framework that integrates three state‑of‑the‑art GCMs (CMIP6‑based) and employs a statistical downscaling technique to generate high‑resolution (0.25°) climate fields across South America. The ensemble weights are optimized using a cross‑validation approach that minimizes mean‑bias error against a 30‑year observational reference dataset (1971‑2000). Performance evaluation reveals that the MME reduces temperature bias by 42 % and precipitation bias by 38 % relative to the best individual GCM, while also decreasing the root‑mean‑square error of seasonal precipitation totals by 27 %. Notably, the ensemble captures extreme precipitation events with a 15 % higher hit rate compared to single‑model outputs. These improvements are attributed to the complementary strengths of the constituent models and the robust weighting scheme. Our results demonstrate that the proposed MME approach substantially enhances the reliability of regional climate projections, offering a valuable tool for policy makers and stakeholders tasked with climate‑resilient planning in vulnerable South‑American regions.
